entry.title: The c/c/c studio
entry.content:
Note to readers: this is my project plan for a Reimagine Fellowship.

table of contents

  • Project Background and Description
  • Project Scope
  • Deliverables
  • Project Sponsor and Stakeholders
  • Success Metrics
  • Business Readiness
  • Key Activities
  • Cost/Time Commitments
  • Risk, Challenges and Dependencies
  • Rapid Analysis
  • Notes for draft readers

Project Background and Description

Elevator pitch

I want to start the c/c/c studio1, an extension/outreach program in creative code (using code to make art + music & other cool things) for ACT High School2 students interested in the intersection of art & technology. Students will be part of a weekly on-campus interactive learning community where they will be guided by instructors in creating their own new works of code-based art & music. At the end of each semester we will host a ‚Äúgrad show‚Äù gallery exhibition/performance of the works from the c/c/c studio. This program will attract fantastic students who might otherwise not study Engineering or Computer Science (either at ANU or elsewhere) and engage the wider community in helping them reimagine what it is to be a Computer Scientist or Engineer in the 21st century.

Problems to be addressed

Interest in Computer Science (CS) education is exploding at all educational levels, but there‚Äôs a lack of support for students in schools which don‚Äôt have specialist teachers or an appropriate learning environment‚Äîespecially for the ‚Äúfun‚Äù stuff which goes beyond textbook exercises. At the ANU we haven‚Äôt done very much to engage at a pre-tertiary level, mostly because we‚Äôre flat-out dealing with the huge growth in students at a tertiary level. The c/c/c studio program will address that.

In addition, CS still suffers from a stereotype of being for ‚Äúnerdy white/asian males‚Äù, and those groups are certainly over-represented in our undergraduate CS cohort compared to other groups. The Reimagine ‚Äúbig tent‚Äù CS education philosophy needs ways of attracting students who don‚Äôt fit the usual CS stereotypes. In attracting & nurturing students who are interested in using computers in the arts & music the c/c/c studio can be one part of that bigger mission.

Undergraduate students at the ANU can take my COMP1720: Art & Interaction in New Media course as part of a major in either a CS degree or a Bachelor of Visual Arts (or indeed as a cross-campus elective in any program). COMP1720 has run successfully as a cross-disciplinary ‚Äúlearn to code‚Äù course for several years. As the A in STEAM, the arts provide an important avenue for engaging students with coding and computer science, especially those who might not normally engage with CS-type activities. The c/c/c studio will extend this opportunity to High School students in the ACT.

Existing alternatives

Some ACT High Schools already have great non-traditional/creative CS/IT programs, for example Dickson College, Radford College, Canberra (Boys) Grammar. I plan to partner with teachers at these schools as early adopters. However, even in these cases there‚Äôs a missing link once students finish High School‚Äîwhere can they go to further develop their creative practice? The c/c/c studio program will give them deep links & relationships into the ANU (across both CS and the Schools of Art & Design and School of Music) and an avenue for continuing their work in this area.

There are a few outreach programs advertised on the CECS website, however the listed programs are dominated by Engineering rather than CS (9 vs 4 programs) and of the 4 CS programs I‚Äôm involved with 2 of them already. There‚Äôs also the official ANU Extension scheme for Year 11 & 12 students in the ACT, however CS doesn‚Äôt yet participate in this scheme.

In the wider ANU context, one similar program is the ANU School of Music‚Äôs Open School of Music. From their website:

The aim of the Open School of Music is to provide developing musicians with a supportive and nurturing social environment in which they can improve their technical and theoretical knowledge of music, interact and share their love of music with their peers, and rub shoulders with the world of professional music-making.

In particular, it aims to ensure that high-quality music education is accessible to all children in the ACT who have the interest and aptitude.

In 2018 I ran the ANU Laptop Ensemble, which attempted to provide a similar open-ended space for creative exploration to the c/c/c studio, but for undergraduate students. I will be drawing on all of these connections & influences in developing the c/c/c studio program during my Reimagine Fellowship.

Project Scope

Solution proposed

The weekly c/c/c studio sessions won‚Äôt be lectures, or even tutorials‚Äîthey will adopt the artist‚Äôs studio model, with each student working on their own code-based music or visual artwork as a semester-long creative ‚Äúwork‚Äù.

The first part of this project is to actually figure out the details of how these workshops will run, but here are some initial plans:

  • each session will be small‚Äîup to 20 students with 1 instructor (Ben) and one tutor
  • students will commit to attending for a semester, with an exhibition/performance at the end
  • students will apply to participate based on interest and aptitude, so we can assume that students are engaged and willing to be self-directed in their learning
  • some ‚Äútraining‚Äù material may be adapted from the COMP1720 lab material and tweaked as appropriate
  • students will be exposed to regular guest ‚Äúprovocations‚Äù from students and creative researchers from CECS, the ANU School of Art & Design, ANU School of Music, ANU Centre for Digital Humanities Research, etc.
  • as well as me (Ben) guiding the students, we will employ one of our undergraduate students as a tutor for these sessions

In addition to the weekly c/c/c studio sessions, we will also run (less frequent) workshops in the High Schools themselves. These workshops will be used to recruit/excite students with the interest and aptitude to attend the c/c/c studio program, to share knowledge and open minds to the sorts of things which are possible with computers and programming, and to strengthen the pathways between the IT programs in ACT High Schools into our CECS undergraduate programs.

Value to organisation/Reimagine strategic alignment

From the Reimagine Project page:

We will inspire a new generation of high-potential, creative people to come to engineering and computing with a diverse range of interests, motivations, perspectives and career aspirations.

The c/c/c studio is designed to attract that new generation and to provide them a supportive community in which to learn, create, and share. More than that, it aims to unlock the latent potential in students who never knew their diverse interests (especially in the arts & music) could be used in engineering and computing.

The c/c/c studio is also an ‚Äúoutwardly-focused education program‚Äù (taken from the Reimagine Fellow position description) which builds two-way relationships with ACT High Schools.

Finally, the c/c/c studio presents an opportunity as an ‚Äúobject lesson‚Äù for the breadth of places that an Engineering/Computer Science skillset can be applied‚Äîa crucial part of Reimagining CECS from a problem-solving to problem-_finding_ institution.

Target users

ACT High School & College students, as well as students from the wider Canberra region (since we could do a travelling version of the workshop).

Also, teachers from these schools will be encouraged to partner with us in both supporting their students to participate in the c/c/c studio, and also to incorporate creative arts & code activities in their classrooms in general (e.g. using the c/c/c studio curriculum, which will be made freely available).

Early adopters

I will build on my (and others) existing relationships with teachers from Dickson College, Radford College, Lyneham High, Canberra (Boys) Grammar and Canberra Girls Grammar. These schools, with their existing groups of students interested in creative code, can give early feedback and serve as ‚Äúseed‚Äù populations for the first semester of c/c/c studio sessions in S1 2020.

Deliverables

This project will deliver:

  • a curriculum (including instructor notes) for the weekly c/c/c studio sessions, which will be freely released to the public under a creative commons licence (CC BY-NC-SA)

  • a biannual c/c/c studio grad show gallery exhibition and music performance held on campus (perhaps in the new cultural centre) as the capstone for each semester‚Äôs student work in the c/c/c studio

There‚Äôll be lots of other stuff, too: building a community of practice, deepening ANU CS/CECS‚Äôs relationships with ACT High Schools, giving our undergraduate students a chance to mentor these high school students, etc. But that‚Äôs intangible stuff, so I‚Äôm not sure if they count as a deliverables.

Project Sponsor and Stakeholders

  • Sponsor: Nick?
  • Owner: Ben Swift
  • Consultations:
    • Alec Hunter (ANU SoM, previously the convenor of the Open School of Music program)
    • Geoff Hinchcliffe (ANU School of Art & Design)
    • Qing Wang (RSCS Associate Director of Education Partnerships)
    • Tony Hosking (RSCS Director)
    • Liz Williams (3Ai Institute) (or perhaps someone else from 3Ai)

Success Metrics

We will judge the success of this program using the following metrics, both in absolute terms and also trends over time.

  • Participation: how many students participate?
  • Retention: for the weekly c/c/c studio sessions, do students keep coming over time?
  • Creative outputs: we‚Äôll have an end-of-semester concert and gallery show‚Äîare the things the students are making any good?
  • Curriculum uptake: is the curriculum developed for the c/c/c studio sessions used by HS teachers to run similar groups in their schools?

Business Readiness

Physical space requirements

The c/c/c studio will require a room for one 2-3 hour session every week in an after-school friendly timeslot (perhaps 4pm-6pm). This room needs to have one computer per student (either a lab machine or personal laptop) which can run a modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari). One of our computer labs in Building #145 should do the job initially.

In addition, some sound gear may be required for the students interested in making music, e.g. headphones & a small mixing desk (I have some of this gear already).

Enrolment/admin requirements

In the short term, it would be great to be able to give students who complete the c/c/c studio program (which will be held in semester-long increments) an official ANU certificate of completion.

Longer-term, it‚Äôd be really great to have the ability to give participants in the c/c/c studio program credit into our first-year CS program (e.g. COMP1720) if they decide to come and study in CECS. This is the same as the equivalent Discovering Engineering extension program, which (I think) gives students credit for a first-year ENGN course if they study Engineering at the ANU.

We will require public liability insurance for any students who come onto campus for the c/c/c studio sessions.

Key Activities

What? Who? By when?
develop relationships with High Schools Ben end 2019
create curriculum Ben end 2019
weekly c/c/c studio sessions Ben + tutor(s) ongoing (beginning 2020)
in-HS workshops Ben + tutor(s) ongoing (beginning 2020)
c/c/c studio grad show students end of semester (beginning mid-2020)

Cost/Time Commitments

Ben: 2 days/week (40% FTE) for 2.5 years (mid 2019-end 2021). This includes:

  1. developing the curriculum
  2. building relationships with High Schools and recruiting students
  3. delivering the weekly c/c/c studio session
  4. running workshops in High Schools (perhaps once a month)

Tutors: depending on how many students attend, it‚Äôd be great to be able to employ one (or more) of our undergraduate students to help support the students in the c/c/c studio.

Equipment: music gear (~2k) so that students can connect their laptops to play together

Grad show budget: (~1k per semester from 2020) for venue/equipment hire (e.g. PA, fancy projectors, etc.)

Estimated project costs: TBD

Risk, Challenges and Dependencies

Risk Who‚Äôs accountable? Mitigation steps When?
students don‚Äôt turn up Ben get buy-in from early adopter schools who are already running this sort of thing ongoing
c/c/c studio doesn‚Äôt meet the requirements for official ANU Extension accreditation Ben, CECS education committee talk to Discovering Engineering people, and if it doesn‚Äôt work it‚Äôs no big deal 2020
ANU arts & music folks feel like we‚Äôre treading on their turf Ben build on existing cross-campus relationships‚Äîkeep them in the loop 2019
too many students Ben introduce some sort of portfolio-based admissions procedure, get ANU UG students to share the teaching load 2020+
students have wide range of different abilities/familiarity with the material Ben, tutors keep class sizes small so we can tailor material to each student, encourage peer-assisted learning at the different stages 2020
project relies too much on Ben‚Äôs particular mix of skills and interests Ben, others get other like-minded folks from inside CECS and across campus involved, train up other CECS people (e.g. tutors) to share the workload 2019

Rapid Analysis

  • Who‚Äîwho is undertaking this role?
  • What‚Äîwhat are they being asked to do?

  • When‚Äîwhen will their role be completed?

  • Recommend
  • Agree
  • Perform
  • Input
  • Decide

This section TODO; see note below.

Notes for draft readers

  • It‚Äôs currently a CS pitch‚Äîthere‚Äôs not much involvement from the Engineering schools at present, although this could change in the future. But I‚Äôve decided to start with what I know.

  • Looking at the Risks section, a lot of it‚Äôs on my shoulders‚Äîneed to fix that.

  • The project proposal part isn‚Äôt super detailed, and that‚Äôs mostly because I need to do some research (discussions with HS teachers, read literature & examine similar programs elsewhere) in the first 6months (mid-late 2019) to figure out those details.

  • This isn‚Äôt exactly what I‚Äôd put in my original pitch, but from discussions in our workshop the other day I think this outreach project hits one of the main goals of the Reimagine project, and is really complementary to the other Fellows‚Äô projects.

  • Some of the nomenclature is still TBC, e.g. the whole ‚Äúc/c/c studio‚Äù thing, code vs tech, art vs music vs creativity, etc. Part of the initial phase of the project will be workshopping these terms to see which ones best resonate with the potential audiences, and also which best capture what actually goes on.

  • I‚Äôm not sure about the RAPID part, I‚Äôm open to suggestions on what that section might mean in the context of this project.

  • It‚Äôs really hard to have all the necessary stakeholder conversations while I‚Äôm on parental leave. So while I‚Äôve discussed this sort of thing to varying degrees with everyone concerned (i.e. I‚Äôm sure no-one would be shocked to hear this project pitch) there‚Äôs a chance that some of the details will change as I make things more concrete and sort out the details.

  1. named after the code/creativity/culture (c/c/c) research group that I lead, which already has some name recognition around the place and will be useful for ‚Äúbranding‚Äù this activity¬†↩

  2. since we‚Äôre in the ACT, I mean Hign School and College (i.e. years 7‚Äì12)¬†↩

entry.title: Mapping over table rows in org-mode

link.title: Mapping over table rows in org-mode

entry.content:
I‚Äôm an Emacs guy, and so if I‚Äôve got some simple tabular data I‚Äôd much rather keep it in an org-mode table than have to fire up Excel.

Here‚Äôs an example:

#+NAME: pap-table
| first name  | last name | yearly-income |
|-------------|-----------|---------------|
| Mr          | Bennett   |          2000 |
| Fitzwilliam | Darcy     |         10000 |
| Charles     | Bingley   |          5000 |

If the prospect of having to keep all those | characters manually aligned is freaking you out, don‚Äôt worry‚Äîorgtbl-mode does it all for you automatically.

Now, I often want to get my functional programming on and apply a function to all the rows of the table. Org-mode does have some special syntax with bunch of cool features for doing arithmetic on the cells (just like Excel formulas) but I‚Äôm usually happier just writing regular elisp to get the job done.

The nicest1 way I‚Äôve found to do this is to give the table a name (in the example above the table name is pap-table‚Äîcan you guess why?). Then, you can tell an elisp code block about the data in that table like so (note the :var table=pap-table at the start):

#+BEGIN_SRC emacs-lisp :var table=pap-table
  (-map
   (lambda (row)
     (cl-destructuring-bind (first last income) row
       (list
        (format "Mr. %s is a man of %s fortune; %s a year."
                last
                (if (< income 2500) "small" "large")
                income))))
   table)
#+END_SRC

Then, when you evaluate the code block with C-c C-c (or just , , in Spacemacs) it‚Äôll return the ‚Äúresult‚Äù:

#+RESULTS:
| Mr. Bennett is a man of small fortune; 2000 a year. |
| Mr. Darcy is a man of large fortune; 10000 a year.  |
| Mr. Bingley is a man of large fortune; 5000 a year. |

This is really handy, as you can imagine. I use it for all sorts of things, including sending ‚Äúmail merge‚Äù emails with template values (since I also use Emacs as my mail client‚Äîsending an email is just an elisp function call away).

Caveats

There are a few ‚Äútricks‚Äù in the above process which took me a while to figure out, so hopefully by listing them here I can save others a bunch of time & hassle.

  • The elisp doesn‚Äôt actually know about the column names from the table‚ÄîI had to re-bind them in the code block using cl-destructuring-bind. Make sure you change the bindings if you change the names/order of the columns in the table!

  • Org-mode tables don‚Äôt have a way of specifying the column ‚Äútype‚Äù, so while it‚Äôll try it‚Äôs best with the basics (e.g. detecting strings vs numbers) sometimes it gets confused. It‚Äôs probably worth putting an explicit e.g. string-to-number in if you want to be sure.

  • In the example above my elisp block returns a value (a list, since I‚Äôm using -map from the excellent dash.el library) and that‚Äôs why the results get nicely formatted in the results block. If your code is side-effectful but doesn‚Äôt return a value then you see the results in that place, you‚Äôll have to look elsewhere (e.g. if you call message you‚Äôll need to look in the *Messages* buffer as usual).

  • Further to the previous caveat, you‚Äôll notice that I‚Äôm actually wrapping the result of the inner lambda in another list, so the output of the code block is actually a list of lists. I could have just returned a list of the strings, but then it would be interpreted as an 1√ón table, rather than the (nicer looking on the page) n√ó1 table shown above.

  1. if there‚Äôs a nicer way, please let me know!¬†↩

entry.title: On parental leave and auto-reply messages

link.title: On parental leave and auto-reply messages

entry.content:
I‚Äôm now (as of the date of this blog post) on parental leave (thanks, Brian üòä). I‚Äôm about to set up an email auto-reply which will guard my work email address until 15 July.

Note: the baby I am taking care of is a human baby, but the above photo contains baby dogs.

Here‚Äôs the deal: I‚Äôm away for a long time, and when I get back in July I‚Äôm going to delete all the unread emails in my inbox. Sorry if that seems harsh, but it‚Äôs the only way to deal with this situation and have any chance of enjoying one‚Äôs return to work.

  • If you‚Äôve got important information which needs to be actioned before July 15, then you need to make alternative arrangements. I wish you all the best, but I can‚Äôt help you out with making it happen.

  • If you‚Äôve got important information which has an expiry date after July 15, then put a note in your calendar to re-email me after that date (because your email still won‚Äôt survive the purge, sorry).

  • If you need to get in touch urgently, then you probably have my personal email or phone number.

  • If you want to organise some sort of hangs/see baby pictures, then try me on my personal email or phone number. I will be pushing a pram around campus at times, and I‚Äôd be keen to catch up.

But doesn‚Äôt that mean you‚Äôll (1) miss a bunch of fantastic opportunities and (2) let a bunch of folks down? Well, maybe. On the first point, I already feel overwhelmed (at times) by the amount of stuff on my to-do list, so any attrition which occurs is actually kindof appealing. And on the second point I‚Äôve tried really hard this last month to hand various things over to capable folks, so I‚Äôm hoping that if we are/were working on something then we‚Äôve made a contingency plan (and that this hasn‚Äôt caught you by surprise).

Anyway, I‚Äôm gonna go be a Dad for a while. I‚Äôll still read the odd book, and maybe even make some more music, but this isn‚Äôt a research fellowship‚Äîit‚Äôs parental leave. Have a great Autumn/Winter, and I‚Äôll see you on the other side.

p.s. I really like the title of this post; inhabiting the liminal space between the the plainspoken declaration ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on parental leave‚Äù and the more philosophical (and pretentious) ‚ÄúOn blah‚Ä¶‚Äù literary device.

entry.title: A dynamic Reimagine logo
entry.content:
I keep harping on about the Reimagine project because I‚Äôm super pumped about what it means for the way we do Engineering Computer Science here at the ANU (see here and here for more info).

Reimagine branding is starting to go up around campus, so I decided to put together an interactive version of the logo (because giant vinyl prints are cool, but they don‚Äôt spin on mouse-over).

It‚Äôs made with clojurescript using Reagent, and as always on my blog you can look at the source to see how it works. If you want to really immerse yourself in the thing, there‚Äôs a fullsreen version here.

If you‚Äôre looking to use this logo yourself in some other page, you could use an <iframe> like so:

<div style="position:relative;padding-top:100%;margin:0;">
  <iframe
    src="https://benswift.me/widgets/reimagine-logo/"
    frameborder="0"
    style="position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;"
  >
  </iframe>
</div>

entry.title: Algorithmic uni marketing billboards
entry.content:
In the spirit of Murdoch University‚Äôs free your think marketing campaign, I‚Äôve put together a dynamic full-page ad billboard as my pitch for the ANU‚Äôs next marketing campaign.

Disclaimer: this is in no way an official ANU campaign. Seriously, though, it‚Äôs a great uni‚Äîand you should come study with us.

The campaign is called: verb your verb‚Äîhit refresh to see the different options.

If you want to see it in fullscreen, you can do that as well.

How does it work?

It uses the same reveal.js template that I use for all my talks/slides‚Äîit‚Äôs basically a one-slide presentation.

Each time the page loads, it:

  1. pulls a random background image from unsplash
  2. chooses two verbs at random from a list of the 1000 most frequently used verbs
  3. places them on the billboard in the form verb your verb, randomising the location and text style

As with all things on this blog, you can check out the source to see all the details.

UPDATE 12 March: I rewrote the billboard code from vanilla js to clojurescript because it makes me happy (source here, and you can still see the original js source here).

entry.title: Reimagining Engineering & CS at the ANU

link.title: Reimagining Engineering & CS at the ANU

entry.content:
The ANU College of Engineering and Computer Science (CECS) is being Reimagined. Don‚Äôt take my word for it; listen to our fearless leader Elanor:

Basically, this Reimagine project is a huge investment from the ANU for CECS to grow, change, and to skate to where the puck is going to be in 2050 (technologically, societally, culturally, and more).

The search is on within CECS to identify Reimagine Fellows to champion various parts of this transformation. This is super-exciting, especially for interdisciplinary art/design/technology folks (like me). It‚Äôd be exciting if it was happening anywhere, but it‚Äôs particularly exciting that it‚Äôs happening where I am and that I might get a voice in shaping exactly what a ‚Äúreimagined CECS‚Äù looks like.

Elanor, if you‚Äôre reading, I want to be a Reimagine Fellow. And since the EoI asked for ‚Äú1000 words in any format you like‚Äù, here‚Äôs mine in the form of an FAQ1.

Ben‚Äôs Reimagine Fellow Application FAQ

In one sentence, why do you want to be a Reimagine Fellow?

I want to see more art2 happening in CECS; and I want to strengthen our education and research ties to the Schools of Art & Design, Music, and Digital Humanities.

What does that have to do with the Reimagine Project?

The role of an artist is to ask questions, not to answer them -Anton Chekhov

As Elanor says in the video above, we don‚Äôt even know what tomorrow‚Äôs problems are yet; so we need problem finders, not just problem solvers. Art and artists have a key role to play in this (just ask Chekov).

Why are you the best person to do this?

I‚Äôve made a career (so far) of deploying my technical/CS skills to artistic ends: in my livecoding (both building tools and doing live gigs), in starting the ANU Laptop Ensemble, in teaching our first-year art+code course COMP1720, etc.

Along the way I‚Äôve built strong networks in these areas across the ANU campus and in the wider community, and I‚Äôve always said that I was keen to engage with them more deeply‚Äîthis is my chance.

So you‚Äôre just trying to score a grant to go off and do your own weird art thing?

Absolutely not. Being a Reimagine Fellow isn‚Äôt about doing something by yourself‚Äîit‚Äôs way too big a project for that. It‚Äôs about weaving something into the whole College3, so that by 2050 it affects the way everyone thinks.

What might this look like, concretely?

The Reimagine Project is big, hairy, and audacious, so it‚Äôs difficult to sketch out a detailed description or org chart. However, here are a few ideas about what it might look like.

In the short term‚Ä¶

  • a CECS-supported ‚ÄúReimagine residency‚Äù (starting asap!) to support artists to get involved and help us figure out what a Reimagined CECS looks like

  • a new code/creativity/culture major (at both undergraduate and masters level) where students take courses from within CECS, the ANU School of Art & Design, and the ANU School of Music

  • new courses within CECS on e.g. algorithmic music composition, creative making, AI/Deep Learning Art, subversive computing/designing for evil4

  • more PhD students doing practice-led research on interdisciplinary art/CS/engineering projects

  • encouraging all CECS academics to engage with their peers and the wider world by making and exhibiting beautiful/interesting/challenging things, not just through journal papers

In the medium/long term‚Ä¶

  • a centre of excellence for digital arts/music/multimedia research, teaching and creative practice (co-hosted by CECS and the College of Arts & Social Sciences)

  • a thoroughly non-traditional project-based ‚Äúcreative tech‚Äù masters program, with no classes, no heirarchies, just a bunch of brilliant students set loose with duct tape, gaming GPUs, a giant bag of sensors & actuators, soldering irons, a 3D printer, oh my. (Geoff Hinchcliffe and I have discussed this‚Äîwe‚Äôre both thrilled and terrified at the prospect. And I love what the 3AI master‚Äôs program is shaping up to be, and am keen to be a part of it.)

  • incorporating into every course5 the option to create and submit a ‚Äúcreative work‚Äù to demonstrate attainment of the learning outcomes (ü§î really Ben?)

I also look forward to having the time to think through what a deeply artistic CECS looks like. I‚Äôm sure that in collaboration with the other Reimagine Fellows and the rest of the design team we can come up even more ideas.

How does this further the broader goals of the Reimagine Project‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶in research?

Artists have always been at the vanguard of building new things (or seeing/using old things in new ways). If an artist has an idea in their head for what they want to create, but the tools to realise it don‚Äôt exist yet, that artist is intrinsically motivated to figure out how to make it happen.

I also want to be clear that my pitch here isn‚Äôt to view the arts as a technical problem that needs to be solved by engineers and computer scientists: ‚Äúhey artists, thanks for the last few thousand years, we‚Äôll take it from here‚Äù. We‚Äôve already got too much technochauvinism in tech. Instead, the pitch is that a newly-Reimagined CECS can include artists in shaping what the computer scientists and engineers of 2050 look like, so that it‚Äôs not an ‚Äúus and them‚Äù.

Some of the top research institutions in the world are asking real questions in the fields of creative technology, digital art, music and design: have a look at the list below.

‚Ä¶in education?

That Chekov quote above really nails it. For some students, being asked to make something creative/artistic is what it takes to flick the switch to go beyond the ‚Äúwhat boxes do I need to tick for me to get a P/CR/D/HD‚Äù mindset to actually asking the right questions. I see this sometimes in COMP1720, and it‚Äôs one of the most enjoyable things about teaching that course.

More broadly, I want to see more dreamers, doodlers and ‚Äúcreatives‚Äù6 study engineering or CS at uni. Too often they feel like they have to choose between ‚Äúpursuing the dream‚Äù or selling out and studying something boring & pragmatic, and I fear that we (CECS) miss out on some brilliant students because of this. I want these students to know that they can pursue their creative dreams, and in doing so they‚Äôll be doing top-class engineering/CS/design work.

‚Ä¶in outreach?

Because of my livecoding I get asked to do outreach stuff all the time (you‚Äôre welcome, CECS marketing team üòâ). I know why I get asked: DJing with code is so different, it‚Äôs a great hook for engaging folks who might not have thought that combining code & musical creativity in that way was possible.

‚Ä¶in culture?

The Reimagine Project isn‚Äôt just about doing the same things under a different org-chart. It‚Äôs about changing the culture of Engineering & Computing research and practice. While the stereotypes about nerdy engineers and computer types isn‚Äôt necessarily fair in my experience, there‚Äôs no smoke without a fire, and there are some things we need to do better. Incorporating the arts and creative expression deep within our education, research and outreach work will change the way we communicate with the outside world, but it‚Äôll also change the sorts of people we attract, and welcoming new perspectives into CECS is another way we can enact cultural change.

Isn‚Äôt this treading on the toes of the School of Art & Design (and the School of Music, and ‚Ä¶)?

No‚Äîin fact we need to work with our colleagues in those places to make this stuff happen. I already co-supervise PhD students with Mitchell & Geoff from the School or Art & Design, and Terhi from the Centre for Digital Humanities Research, and I run the ANU Laptop Ensemble with Alec from the School of Music. And I want to see more of this type of cross-supervision across these parts of campus.

Actually, this ‚Äútreading on toes‚Äù question looms over the whole Reimagine Project. I think the best way forward is to partner with the other parts of campus to bring their expertise and smoosh it together with ours.

Concretely, that means:

  • sending CECS coursework students to take courses in other parts of campus (as part of majors/minors/electives, etc.) as well as the other way around
  • co-employing academics across Colleges in joint positions
  • increasing our to participation in the ANU‚Äôs interdisciplinary HDR programs like ICCR

Where in the world is this already happening?

Here‚Äôs a few places, including what each place says about their goals (from the marketing copy on their own website). Many (but not all) of these labs/groups are in CS/Engineering Schools, or at least in design schools.

The MIT Media Lab is an interdisciplinary research lab that encourages the unconventional mixing and matching of seemingly disparate research areas.

The Frank-Ratchye STUDIO for Creative Inquiry at Carnegie Mellon University is a laboratory for atypical, anti-disciplinary, and inter-institutional research at the intersections of arts, science, technology and culture.

SensiLab is a technology-driven, design-focused research lab based at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia.

NYU‚Äôs ITP (Interactive Telecommunications Program) is a two-year graduate program located in the Tisch School of the Arts whose mission is to explore the imaginative use of communications technologies.

The Centre for Digital Music (c4dm) at Queen Mary University of London is a world-leading multidisciplinary research group in the field of Music & Audio Technology.

The Embodied AudioVisual Interaction (EAVI) group at Goldsmiths is a research group focused on embodied interaction with sound and image.

The Stanford Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics (CCRMA) is a multi-disciplinary facility where composers and researchers work together using computer-based technology both as an artistic medium and as a research tool.

The School for Poetic Computation is an artist run school in New York that was founded in 2013. A small group of students and faculty work closely to explore the intersections of code, design, hardware and theory ‚Äî focusing especially on artistic intervention. It‚Äôs a hybrid of a school, residency and research group.

The Arts and Creativity Lab at the National University of Singapore provides an environment for arts-driven research and technology development, as well as artistic practice and experimentation related to scientific research methods and results

Has the ANU ever had anything like this before?

Sure, for example this, and it was amazing. The story about why ACAT is no longer around is long, and I‚Äôve only really ever heard it second/third-hand, and I‚Äôm not proposing to resurrect ACAT as part of the Reimagine Project. But it‚Äôs important to know one‚Äôs history.

Sounds like a huge job, Ben‚Äîhow are you going to manage it?

Not on my own, that‚Äôs for sure. Only by building up our capacity in these areas. As an example, Dr. Charles Martin is just about to start as a new Lecturer in RSCS, and he‚Äôs a computer musician (apps and ML for group musical improvisation). The campus also has many other interdisciplinary artists who have been hiding their lights under bushels‚ÄîI want to give them a banner to rally to.

We need to think big, and I look forward to a day where there‚Äôs a long list of academic staff & PhD students exploring new avenues for technologically and culturally sophisticated artistic practice within CECS and the broader ANU campus. That‚Äôs what I want us to be famous for.

Do you really get asked these questions frequently, Ben?

No.

So is it really fair to call it an FAQ?

Probably not. Sorry.

Footnotes

  1. At least it‚Äôs not a haiku. Or a limerick.¬†↩

  2. Defining ‚Äúart‚Äù is beyond the scope of this blog post, obviously. But I don‚Äôt just mean it in the narrow ‚Äúhigh/fine art‚Äù sense, although I don‚Äôt mean it in the ‚Äúall the humanities‚Äù sense either. Think making music, drawing pictures, writing stories‚Äîbut with an element of technology in the mix.¬†↩

  3. You could even say ‚Äúweaving it into the College‚Äôs DNA‚Äù. But that‚Äôd be dumb. Institutions don‚Äôt have DNA‚Ä¶ except maybe RSB.¬†↩

  4. I‚Äôd love to get Genevieve to write & teach that one.¬†↩

  5. I kindof want to wriggle out and say most courses, but I also really want to see what an artistic submission in lieu of a final exam looks like for COMP3600.¬†↩

  6. Although I reject the Romantic notion that ‚Äúcreatives‚Äù are some sort of rarefied ‚Äúother‚Äù, conduits to some deep wellspring of hidden creative mojo from the other side. We‚Äôre all just humans, constructing and engaging in cultural practices with this stuff, building on what went before.¬†↩

entry.title: Class discussions on Discourse
entry.content:
In 2018 I (with the support of the Teaching & Learning IT team in my School) switched from Piazza to a self-hosted Discourse instance for class discussions. Specifically, I used it for COMP1720: Art & Interaction in New Media, a large-ish (~200 students) introductory code/art programming and interaction design course. This course is open to both CS and non-CS students, and can be counted towards a major in both the CS and the ANU School of Art and Design.1

This wasn‚Äôt because Piazza sucks‚Äîit‚Äôs actually pretty great in lots of ways. But there were a few things we hoped to that Discourse would do better:

  1. integration with the rest of our class management infrastructure (so that the professor doesn‚Äôt have to keep adding/students manually as enrolment grows and then settles down at the start of semester)

  2. a proper API, rather than using one of the unofficial Piazza API clients and hoping that Piazza didn‚Äôt break things just before an assigment/exam

  3. proper markdown support (with the ability to add whichever programming languages we like through highlight.js integration) rather than whatever they call the nonsense pseudo-markdown and flaky rich text editor that Piazza offers

  4. self-hosting and controlling where the data is stored, because I don‚Äôt think I ever figured out whether it was technically ok to store student data on a foreign server and compel students to create an account on same

  5. a plugin ecosystem so that we could tweak it to suit our specific needs (and potentially develop our own plugins)

Still, there are a couple of things that Discourse is missing out-of-the-box compared to Piazza:

  1. the ability for instructors (professors & tutors) to mark a question/answer as a good question/answer (really handy in teaching)

  2. the ability for students to ‚Äúpost anonymously to other students‚Äù while still being visible (identifiable) to the instructors

  3. ability for students to ‚Äúaccept‚Äù an answer, SO-style (there‚Äôs a plugin for this, but we didn‚Äôt use it first time around)

So how‚Äôd it go?

Pretty well‚Äîstudent engagement was higher than the previous year (with Piazza) and anecdotal feedback was that the students liked it. The limitations described above didn‚Äôt bite too hard, although I do think that the ‚Äúpost anonymously to students‚Äù thing in particular does encourage students to speak up when they‚Äôre struggling in a way that they don‚Äôt when their name is attached to everything.

Along the way, we also made some decisions about how to organise/administer a Discourse server for use as a course forum. Since Discourse isn‚Äôt specifically designed for this task, we had to make a few choices, and it‚Äôs worth laying them out here in case anyone else is going down the same path. Note, you‚Äôll need to get your head around the Discourse nomenclature if you‚Äôre going to use it, but the crash course is

  • threads are called topics
  • topics are grouped into categories and subcategories (but only 2 levels max‚Äîno subsubcategories)
  • groups are groups of users

So, the way we organised it was:

  • each course is a category
  • subcategories were devoted to e.g. lectures, labs, assignments, etc.
  • access control: all students were enrolled into a group, which was given read/write access to the category with the same name2
  • tutors (TAs) were given

Here‚Äôs an example: for COMP1720 we set up

  • a top-level comp1720 category
  • a comp1720 group (in which all students in the course were automatically enrolled using the Discourse API)
  • all tutors are members of a comp1720-tutors group, which has a higher privilege level

This way, if a student is enrolled in multiple courses, they‚Äôll appear in multiple groups. They‚Äôll have access to all the topics in the categories for their courses, but not any topics from other course (of course).

One final bonus is that the default ‚Äúhomepage‚Äù for a logged in user shows the latest posts across all the user‚Äôs categories (although users can customise this behaviour).

Next steps

I‚Äôve got a student who‚Äôs working hard to develop a new plugin to restore the ‚Äúanon to students, visible to instructors‚Äù behaviour, since that‚Äôs a deal-breaker for a lot of folks (it nearly was for me as well). We‚Äôll release that plugin when it‚Äôs done and the kinks are worked out.

There are still things to figure out as well, but things are looking good. I wouldn‚Äôt go back; I think it‚Äôs easier to add the things I miss from Piazza to Discourse than the other way around.

If you‚Äôve got experience with this sort of thing and have suggestions or comments, then get in touch (@benswift or ben.swift@anu.edu.au)

  1. I also teach all the artists & designers to use git‚Äîand it works really well‚Ä¶ with the appropriate scaffolding. Knowing how to use version control really does feel like having superpowers when editing digital, and seeing artists and designers realise this is pretty cool.¬†↩

  2. the course category (list of topics) and group (list of members) could in principle have different names¬†↩

entry.title: On livecoding annotations and visualisations
entry.content:
I‚Äôve just finished reading Charlie Roberts‚Äô interactive web essay on annotations and visualisations for live code. If you haven‚Äôt read it, go do that now‚Äîand make sure you have some speakers/headphones to listen to the code examples, because it would be a real shame to read it without watching/listening to his ideas in action. All the code samples (with the visual annotations) are live-editable, both running ‚Äúwhole blocks‚Äù and re-evaluating individual expressions with ctrl+enter.

The essay lays out some guiding principles:

There are three principles that guide the design of the presented annotations and visualizations.

  1. If a value changes over time (typically related to musical progression or signal processing), display its current state, either by adding a visualization / annotation or by modifying the source code to reflect the current value.
  2. Make annotations and visualizations as proximal as possible to the code fragment responsible for generating the data they are representing.
  3. In addition to displaying when values change, whenever possible also provide some indication of when a value is being read, in particular when there is a direct affect on musical / sonic output.

It then goes on to show some example visualisation in gibberwocky, both in an ‚Äúall in‚Äù demo and then in bite-sized listings which show off the different specific ideas. In general, I really like the ideas, and it‚Äôs something Andrew Sorensen and I have written about before in our paper Visual Code Annotations for Cyberphysical Programming (2013) in the 1st International Workshop on Live Programming (LIVE)1 (it‚Äôs reference #4 in the essay). I‚Äôll refer to this a bit in this post, so let‚Äôs call it ‚Äúthe LIVE paper‚Äù.

I also think that the three points listed above are pretty solid, especially in a multimedia livecoding context (maybe even in a broader context). One thing I like about the visual annotations provided is that they‚Äôre mostly ASCII (or ASCII-ish). This is not so important when deploying them in the web browser (since you can do so much fancy styling stuff with CSS & js these days) but it‚Äôs really important when dealing with‚Ä¶ ahem, more venerable editors. I ended up having to use some unholy Emacs hacks with overlays to get the original annotations discussed in the LIVE paper working.

I think that displaying hidden state in comments is a good compromise, and avoids the need for fancy ‚Äúextra-textual‚Äù overlays. Not that overlays aren‚Äôt sometimes useful, but there‚Äôs a lot you can show with inline text-decoration hacks and adding a few comments to provide ascii text to decorate (when it isn‚Äôt explicitly represented in the first place).

Mixing annotations and live edits

But, (you can probably tell that there was going to be a ‚Äúbut‚Äù somewhere) many of the cool annotations displayed don‚Äôt work while the code is being edited2. In some cases they actually break the code (try editing one of the 'x*ox*xo--x*x*o' patterns while the code‚Äôs running‚Äîyou‚Äôll end up with new stuff in your pattern that you didn‚Äôt put there).

The problem isn‚Äôt so obvious when all the code listings are fully-formed on page load, and you can just play them as is. But when you try and mess with the code then you‚Äôll see what I mean (again, I really suggest that you try it‚Äîit‚Äôs super-cool being able to mess around with the live code in the browser).

I feel this particularly keenly because I‚Äôm a clean-slate livecoder (as is Charlie), so I‚Äôm always moving through an incomplete code state until I get something which will even run. This isn‚Äôt just a problem for clean-slate livecoding, though‚Äîeven tweaks to existing code which introduce ‚Äúbad‚Äù code states (from the visualisation‚Äôs perspective) will cause these issues.

We talked about this in the LIVE paper‚Äîthe fact that there‚Äôs a distinction between the ‚Äústate of the world‚Äù vs ‚Äústate of the code‚Äù. This is a fundamental challenge for the sorts of inline code visualisation/annotations shown in the essay, because it‚Äôs using the code as the ‚Äúraw material‚Äù for displaying information about the world (beat/timing and other ‚Äúhidden variables‚Äù, audio engine state and output, etc.).

There are a few different ways to tackle this problem:

  1. mark some annotations as ‚Äúsafe‚Äù for code being edited, and some ‚Äúunsafe‚Äù
  2. when code is being edited, turn off all annotations (or at least for that expression)
  3. some sort of ‚Äúgrand unified theory‚Äù of the delta between the current code state and the current execution state, and reconcile these to provide a maximal set of acceptable visualisations (this approach includes a coq program to formally verify that you‚Äôre doing everything right)

I think the pragmatic choice is #2, as long as the ‚Äúdisabled edits‚Äù section is kept as small as possible. It‚Äôs still going to be a pain, though, because when I‚Äôm livecoding I‚Äôm tweaking stuff all the time, so it‚Äôs likely that a lot of the code will spend a lot of the time with the visualisations disabled.

I‚Äôll leave #3 up to people smarter than me üòÅ (although perhaps there are heuristics which could do a decent job).

Finally, I can identify with Charlie when he writes:

But, in the end, the feedback provided by these annotations and visualizations have become a critical part of my live coding practice.

I get this‚Äîin my experience (when I‚Äôve had even more limited annotations than the ones he shows in the essay) are just as much for my benefit as the audience. Livecoding is hard, and any extra information you can get about what‚Äôs going on with your code is super helpful.

In principle visual code annotations can be even more useful to the livecoder because they allow her to ‚Äúaudition‚Äù algorithmic changes to the code without3 actually eval-ing the code and changing the music. Here‚Äôs an example from the essay:

Euclid(9, 16); /* 1010110101011010 */

I might not always know what the 9,6 euclidean rhythm is, but I‚Äôm by now fairly used to looking at 10100010 sequences and ‚Äúhearing‚Äù the rhythm in my head. I could poke around with the parameters in a live set, exploring the parameter space (and thinking through the effect it‚Äôll have on the music) and then only evaluating the code when I‚Äôm satisfied. That‚Äôs super powerful‚Äîthe equivalent of the DJ cueing the next track with one can on their ear, and one ear in the club‚Äîsomething which I don‚Äôt have currently in my livecoding setup (although others might).

Conclusion

You can probably tell that I think there‚Äôs a productive research agenda here‚Äîand I hope Charlie continues with it. I hope to help out myself, too. I guess my main point is just to shout from the rooftops:

any code visualisation/annotation techniques must be robust for code which is currently being edited

I‚Äôm not just talking about technical issues, either; obviously any demo/prototype is going to have those, but they‚Äôre fixable. I think there are deeper issues with trying to use live text as both the description of program behaviour and as a ‚Äúview‚Äù on the hidden state of the program.

Anyway, this is just a blog post, so I‚Äôm off the hook with regard to rigour, accountability and just general good scholarship, right üòú

Addendum: thoughts on web publishing

I love that this essay/paper is published online‚Äîthe interactive examples are crucial to getting the point across. I know that some conferences & journals these days allow html submission (nicer for reading on mobile, anyway) and other multimedia artefacts (audio/video recordings) but it‚Äôs still hard to get traction for this sort of rich, interactive in-browser work. The fact that at the end Charlie has to say:

If you‚Äôre going to cite this website in an academic paper, please consider also citing either reference #1 or reference #7 given above; citations of such papers count more in academia than citations of a website. Plus, there‚Äôs further information in them not covered in this essay. Thank you!

Oh well. Mad props to Charlie for putting this out there for comment and discussion, and hopefully there are a new generation of publications4 where this stuff can be front-and-centre, not just a weird ‚Äúsupplemental web materials‚Äù section to a traditional pdf.

  1. if you don‚Äôt have institutional access to the IEEE then just email me and I can send you a pre-print.¬†↩

  2. Charlie, if I‚Äôm doing it wrong, please let me know :)¬†↩

  3. Yes, I know that the real-time feedback of hearing the sound is crucial, and I‚Äôm not for a second saying that we do away with it, but there are some situations where I want to check what the result of an algorithmic/parameter change might be without inflicting it on the audience.¬†↩

  4. Distill is great, but it‚Äôs pretty DL/AI-focussed. The livecoding community needs something similar (although it does privilege livecoding environments which work in the brower, so that‚Äôs not ideal either. Hmm.)¬†↩

entry.title: Oils from Â®ÅÊµ∑
entry.content:
One of my academic responsibilities is teaching our ANU Computer Science programs into our various partner institutions overseas. One of these partner institutions is Shandong University WeiHai (SDUW).

On my trip to SDUW in May 2016, I was walking across the campus one bright spring morning when I was stopped by a professor from the SDUW School of Art. Through his limited English and my much more limited Mandarin, he told me that he wanted me to sit for a portrait session for his first-year painting class.

After a marathon 4hr sitting1, here‚Äôs what the students came up with. As a bonus, I got to choose my favourite one and bring it home‚Äîcan you guess which one I chose?

It‚Äôs now hanging on my wall at home, creepily looking down at my family and our guests. I love it.

  1. that‚Äôs why I look so sullen‚ÄîI smiled no-stop for the first hour (when they were painting the background) but by the time they were putting on the facial details 3hrs in I was way too tired to keep my smile up üòä¬†↩
